lines.text: The war started when people accepted the idiotic principle that peace could be maintained by arranging to defend themselves with weapons they couldn't possibly use without committing suicide.
I shouldn't drink, you know. I inevitably say something brilliant.

The trouble with you is you want a simple answer. There isn't any. The war started when people accepted the idiotic principle that peace could be maintained - - by arranging to defend themselves with weapons they couldn't possibly use - - without committing suicide. Everybody had an atomic bomb, and counter-bombs, and counter-counter bombs. The devices outgrew us; we couldn't control them. I know, I helped build them. God, help me. Somewhere, some poor bloke probably looked at a radar screen and thought he saw something. He knew that if he hesitated one-thousands of a second - his own country would be wiped off the map. So - So, he pushed a button - and the world went - - crazy. And, and...
There isn't time. No time to love... nothing to remember... nothing worth remembering.
They pushed us too far! They didn't think we'd fight, no matter what they did!
And they were wrong. We fought. We expunged them. And we didn't do such a bad job on ourselves.
There was a choice. It was build the bombs, and use them - or risk the United States, the Soviet Union, and the rest of us, would find some way... to go on living.

[scoffs]
That's wishful thinking if ever I heard it.

[softly]
I'm not against wishful thinking. Not now.
Mr. Osborne, he's doing a good job for us. He's not used to this kind of duty. He's not feeling well; just a little claustrophobia.
Beg your pardon, sir?
Professor needs a drink.
In the end, somehow granted the time for examination, we shall find that our so called civilization was gloriously destroyed by a handful of vacuum tubes and transistors. Probably faulty.

Now, this is a special kind of - - sleeping pill. I had a devil of a time getting 'em. But, I wanted you to have them on hand and to make sure you knew how to use 'em. - - What happens with the radiation is that you get - you get ill - and you start feeling sick and then you are sick and you go on being sick. You can't keep anything down. You may feel better for awhile; but, but it always comes back. You get weaker.
And this cures it.
Darling, you know nothing cures it. This ends it.
Well... how'd you recognize me?
I love Americans. They're so naive.
I wouldn't really mind... if you could forget entirely who I am... I don't like myself very much anyway.
You remember when we first met? It was on the beach. I thought you were everything I'd always wanted.
I thought you were so underfed.
It's all over now, isn't it?
Yes, it's all over.
We're all doomed, you know. The whole, silly, drunken, pathetic lot of us. Doomed by the air we're about to breathe. We haven't got a chance!
Stop it! I won't have it, Julian. I won't! There is hope. There has to be hope. There's always hope. We just can't go on like this. We can't. We - we...
[first lines]
Prepare to surface.
[last lines]
God... God, forgive us. Peter, I think I'll have that cup of tea now.
Who do you think started it - the war?
Albert Einstein.
There's one thing that always bothered me, Hosgood. A girl like you - why no young men?
They never asked me. I guess maybe it was the uniform.

[Toast]
To a blind, blind world.
Who would ever have believed that human beings would be stupid enough to blow themselves off the face of the Earth?
Dwight... even if you don't like me, would you please hold on to me just for a moment longer?
You know, I think I've discovered why you fascinate me. Shall I tell you?
Uh-huh.

Because you take me for granted. I know women aren't supposed to like that sort of thing, but somehow I do. I've been treated in every other way. Like a child. And sometimes like - well, like things I've probably deserved. But I've never been pushed around in - in such a nice way and treated something like a wife. - - I suppose what I mean is - like an American wife.

[as she is bent over wearing a bathing suit, Peter snaps a towel on Mary's behind]
Peter, how could you!
Oh, I don't know, really, I just held the towel like this and...
Very funny.
You're starting to get your figure back, arent' ya... You know, after Jennifer and all. Little here. A little there.
Was he married, do you know?
Two kids.
And there gone.
Yes, they were in America.
We would have to get someone for him, wouldn't we? What about Moira?
Well, why not, if she's sober this weekend.
Julian said she's given it up.
Oh, no, darling, you didn't listen. Julian said she'd given up gin - for brandy. She says she can drink more brandy.
Moira's not a bad notion, point of fact.
You're looking for me.
Am I?
I'm Moira Davidson. M-O-I-R-A. It was a very fashionable name when... my mother was young and impressionable. I'm a throwback.
Where's Holmes?
Oh, he's decking the halls with holly. He sent me for better or worse.
Better, I'd say.
I'm your date - or, whatever you call it.
Is there a place where I might stop where I can get a little breakfast?
What?
A little breakfast.
Do you mean that in addition to everything else, I have to watch you eat bacon and eggs and all that muck?
You have to buy me a couple of drinks to get me started.

My second husband was an American. We traveled all over the world - and everywhere we went he say to people, "I am an American. I am an American." They finally shot him in one of those eastern countries.
I can't decide if I'm more objectionable drunk or sober?
if everybody was so smart, why didn't they know what would happen?
They did.
Well, I - I can't take it. I - oh, yes, I can take it! But, it's unfair. It's unfair because I didn't do anything. And nobody I know did anything.
The only thing I could understand is geography. And I like geography.
A very nice man asked me to wait here. I don't think he knew what to do with me.
That's debatable.
I take it you put me to bed?
I've never had it happen quite like that before.
My obvious job was to seduce you. So, I suppose my pride is hurt. I also feel ashamed.

[to Moira]
Well, you can't go down in a submarine in that ballet costume.
It's like looking at a French movie.
When the dentist is drilling your tooth, what do you think about? The nicest thing or sex or what?
Fishing. Trout fishing - in a clean mountain stream.
You never wrestle with me any more.
Now, what does that mean?
I mean exactly what I say, you never wrestle with me any more.
Wouldn't you like to try?
Have you ever been to San Francisco?
Yes, I have. A week on the way down. I met a lovely girl. Longest, loveliest legs I've ever seen. Full of martinis - both of them. The legs, I mean.
Is your invitation to spread a little fertilizer still open?

[Smiles, laughs]
Can you stay for a few day?
Would you have a glass of sherry - with an old man?
No, sir. But, I would very much like to have one with you, sir.
Now, it's all over, isn't it?
It's all over.

[Last lines]
Darling.
God, God forgive us. Peter, I think I'll have that cup of tea, now.
